caption_text: The tube layout, orifice design and hole arrangement are shown in Fig. 2. Twelve thin-walled (nominal wall thickness 0.2 0.28 mm) palladium membrane tubes, each hav- ing an outside diameter of 4.7 mm, were supplied by Johnson Matthey Ltd. The palladium used for tube fabrication has a purity of 99.95%.

Twelve thin-walled (nominal wall thickness 0.2 0.28 mm) palladium membrane tubes, each hav- ing an outside diameter of 4.7 mm, were supplied by Johnson Matthey Ltd.
The palladium used for tube fabrication has a purity of 99.95%.

caption_text: All are connected to pressure lines as shown in Fig. 3. Each purging line has an inside diameter of 2mm and is equipped with a flowmeter and a regulating valve to provide a controlled, preoptimized velocity of an inert gas. The purging velocity was typically 0.4 mIs, not high enough to interfere with the measured signal yet high enough to prevent catalyst particles from being entrained into the probe tubes.

caption_text: Hydrogen yield (defined as the total number of moles of hydrogen produced divided by the number of moles of methane equivalent fed to the system) and the hydrogen permeation flow through the membrane tube wall are plotted in Fig. 6 for the same five eases. The dependence of the hydrogen permeability on the reactor bed temperature is clear from this figure. The hydrogen yields confirm the widening gap between the performance of the two types of reactors with increasing temperature.

caption_text: The 14 cases included in Fig. 8 cover a wide range of permeation conditions, yet the Kutsata et al. (1979) equation with a constant fitted value for ~q,,, is able to give good predictions for all cases. From the good agreement between the calculated and experimental values for the permeation rates, it is reasonable to assume that the factors noted above which affect the permeation process alter the overall permeation effectiveness but not the mechanisms nor the tern- perature dependence.

caption_text: Under the same operating conditions, this table compares experimental data obtained without per- meation in a fluidized bed reactor (FBR) and data obtained with permeation in the novel membrane C 0 C S reactor (FBMR). The calculated reaction conversions and product compositions in an ideal continuous stirred tank reactor (CSTR) operated under the average bed eonditions are also reported.
raw_window: Under the same operating conditions, this table compares experimental data obtained without per- meation in a fluidized bed reactor (FBR) and data obtained with permeation in the novel membrane C 0 C S reactor (FBMR).
The calculated reaction conversions and product compositions in an ideal continuous stirred tank reactor (CSTR) operated under the average bed eonditions are also reported.
The data indicate a methane conversion in the FBR close to or greater than the corresponding CSTR conversion for 0.7 0.6 0.5 0.4 0.3 0.2 0.1 540 560 580 600 620 640 660 Temperature, C Fig. 4.
table_reason: The caption ends after S1, as S2 contains figure reference and data not part of the table description.

caption_text: The results in Table 2 demonstrate that the novel reactor system leads to reaction conversions beyond the conventional limits by virtue of the selective separation and removal of product hydrogen from the reacting gas mixture. The increase in steam conver- sion is significantly higher than the increase in methane conversion. This finding, confirmed in almost all the reaction permeation experiments in the present study, demonstrates the tendency of the FBMR to produce more hydrogen from steam (the component introduced in excess) than from methane (the yield-limiting component) compared to both the FBR and CSTR.
raw_window: The results in Table 2 demonstrate that the novel reactor system leads to reaction conversions beyond the conventional limits by virtue of the selective separation and removal of product hydrogen from the reacting gas mixture.
The increase in steam conver- sion is significantly higher than the increase in methane conversion.

This finding, confirmed in almost all the reaction permeation experiments in the present study, demonstrates the tendency of the FBMR to produce more hydrogen from steam (the component introduced in excess) than from methane (the yield-limiting component) compared to both the FBR and CSTR.

As the bed temperature increases, the conversion increases due to both the reaction equilib- rium and faster kinetics.
Simultaneously the permea- tion rate, which is temperature-dependent, increases and shifts the reaction equilibrium towards higher conversion and hydrogen production.
